meanings.definition: To have a retrospective effect or influence.
meanings.sent1: The new rule will retroact to last year's policies.
meanings.sent2: The change in leadership retroacted on the company's culture.
meanings.sent3: His apology retroacted back to the argument they had last week.
meanings.sent4: The memories of childhood retroact upon our present emotions.
meanings.sent5: The music retroacted me to a time of carefree joy.

meanings.definition: To apply a law or decision to a past event.
meanings.sent1: The court's ruling will retroact to the incident from two years ago.
meanings.sent2: The new regulation retroacted to cases that happened before its implementation.
meanings.sent3: The teacher's grading system retroacted to the missed assignments.
meanings.sent4: The policy change retroacted to the previous fiscal year's budget.
meanings.sent5: The updated guidelines retroacted to all previous violations.

meanings.definition: To act in a way that affects a previous time.
meanings.sent1: Her decision to leave retroacted on their past relationship.
meanings.sent2: The discovery retroacted to the historical records of the town.
meanings.sent3: His words retroacted to the promises made long ago.
meanings.sent4: The new technology retroacted to the outdated methods used before.
meanings.sent5: The actions taken retroacted to a time of prosperity.
